Medical debt can also be triggered by other people, which is atypical (outside of fraud):

- If someone calls 911 on your behalf, you get the bill for the paramedics/ambulance/ER.

- If someone shoot you and you go to the hospital, you get billed for that. (Yay, US healthcare!)

Very good move, though I wonder why it’s going to take until 2023 to stop reporting debts under $500.

From a technology perspective, this should be trivial.

My favorite gas station and price transparency story involves two gas stations near Orlando airport. 

They didn’t have price signs. When you got there, you found that gas was 2-3x what it cost elsewhere. But faced with alternative of paying $12/gal to hertz, you sucked it up.

@felixsalmon @EmilyRPeck I’m saying that comment is elitist. … As someone who has had that *exact* thought.

Many of us city dwellers take transit (I did when I lived in NYC), drive EVs (I do now), or have short commutes.
Most people don’t have the luxury of ignoring gas prices. Even without the signs, they would feel it when they go to make the charge. It is material. A jump from $50 to $100 is a big deal.

#psychology #pricing how much do the giant signs advertising prices in 1 1/2 foot numbers affect our collective view on the economy. @EmilyRPeck brought this up in slate money with @felixsalmon 

A thought I’ve had before, but I came to the conclusion that it’s an elitist view. https://t.co/AkM603Js1a

Trade shows are another example of the hybrid nature:
- marketing drives traffic to the booth and events, creates messaging, prepares collateral and collects leads 
- sales takes those leads onto acquire new customers and works with existing customers to nurture relationships.

Sales and marketing are also fundamentally different. 

In general (very generally)
- marketing is more important to B2C
- sales is more important to B2B

Many companies are hybrid: marketing to consumers to get eyeballs; sales to businesses to sell those eyeballs.

Very few people can do all of these well. Especially when you’re trying to use people with the wrong goal or you have a misunderstanding of timelines. Eg if you think you’re going to sell into a major telco in three months, you will be disappointed. (1 year would be phenomenal).

If your sales team is full of low-skill people, you’re doing it wrong. 

Especially in B2B, sales teams are key to success. 

But you need to know what you need at each stage: biz development, early-stage sales, inside sales, outside sales, solutions engineering, customer success https://t.co/27NdEICLkQ

One of the unintended but foreseeable consequences questions I ask during product interviews:

A toll bridge has peak pricing of $8 between 5 am and 10 am. At other times it has a toll of $6. What was a big negative consequence?

Good piece on second-order effects and unintended consequences. Important when designing products and services. You can’t necessarily predict them all, but it is good to at least think about them.

@vmarks @johnkoetsier general content consumption is the one that comes to mind for me.

I don't want to download your app before I can read the story I just came to read.

@johnkoetsier There’s a great series by @rklau on OKRs.

If he had an OKR for this content, it would likely be “Educate people on how to set OKRs,” not “create an app to educate people on how to set OKRs.”

@johnkoetsier So why do companies invest in apps (and usually 2 apps) when they could do the same with an easier to deploy and maintain mobile site?

One reason: poorly set OKRs. You get a step toward a promotion by building the app, not doing the best thing to serve the customer.

@johnkoetsier e.g. Google has an app for search, it also has a mobile site for search. I almost always use the site because the app adds little value.

OTOH, for maps, the app adds tremendous value so I use the app.
@johnkoetsier Forcing me to install an app for things that don’t require access to specialized  phone capabilities is likely to make me find something that does.

Only 91%?

If something can easily be done by mobile Web, it’s vanity to try to force people into a mobile app.

Maybe once you’ve delivered value?
